discussion.content:
1. git reset --hard && git checkout example_branch
throw away uncommited changes (reset working tree and index)

2. git revert ac40974fe8 && git merge master
revert the potential conflicting change and merge master into the current (example_branch) branch

3. Reapply the change and run "git add -A && git commit"
make the change again and commit it

4. git checkout master && git merge example_branch
switch to the master branch and merge example_branch into it

5. git push
push the changes to the remote master branch

git reset --hard && git checkout example_branch
 git revert ac40974fe8 && git merge master
 Reapply the change and run "git add -A && git commit"
 git checkout master && git merge example_branch
 git push

git reset ...
git revert ...
Reapply ...
git push
git checkout ...

questions.question_text: What is an advantage of the Agile software development method as compared to Waterfall?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

choices.A: In Agile the development teams deliver the whole project at once, and in Waterfall the project is delivered in phases.
choices.D: In Agile each development team works independently, and in Waterfall the development team collaborate.
choices.B: In Agile the customer involvement is limited to the requirement collection phase, and in Waterfall the customer is involved in all development phases.
choices.C: In Agile every aspect of development is continually revisited, and in Waterfall the revision takes place in another project.
It improves code availability by distributing the data across different machines.
choices.E: It executes tests and reveals compilation errors before the code is committed.
choices.A: It enables multiple team members to work on the same project simultaneously.
choices.D: It provides automation of the build and deployment process out of the box.
choices.B: It provides a complete long-term change history of every file of an application.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A,B are correct

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of using version control? (Choose two.)

A system administrator works with a software development department to implement code to production. The administrator wants to review the code to be implemented and not do it automatically. The code must be ready for production and should be implemented by the administrator without additional intervention from the development team. Which DevOps concept does this scenario represent?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B, as per chatgpt.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

A is wrong - We don't use NETCONF for device-level management
C is wrong - Controller is not standards-based, it is proprietary to each vendor (for example Cisco DNA Center)
D is wrong - Controller exposes only Northbound and Southbound APIs

comments.content: D is the one that makes sense to me too.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the only one that makes sense. Opinions?

questions.question_text: What is a difference between device-level and controller-level infrastructure management?

choices.B: Controller-level management uses APIs to simplify the developer experience, whereas device-level management uses traditional management protocols.
choices.A: Device-level management uses NETCONF, whereas controller-level management does not support NETCONF to automate the infrastructure.
choices.D: Controller-level management exposes northbound, southbound, eastbound, and westbound APIs, easing integration with other technologies, whereas device-level management does not use a controller-based API.
choices.C: Controller-level management is more widely supported because it is standards-based, whereas device-level management is proprietary to each vendor.
